subSubSection.paragraph:
Sonerila souvannii
sp. nov. is similar to
S. cardamomensis
, described from Cambodia , in its acaulescent habit and in the shape of its leaves, but it differs in the shape of its rhizome (cylindrical in
S. souvanii
vs bulbous in
S. cardamomensis
), larger leaves (8â€“10 Ã— 6â€“9 cm vs 1â€“4 Ã— 0.9â€“2.7 cm ), petiole length and color ( 8â€“15 cm long and light green vs 0.4â€“2.5 cm long and reddish brown), greater number of flowers per cyme (20â€“25 vs 5â€“11), and petal length and pubescence (9â€“10 Ã— 6â€“7 mm and glabrous vs 5.5â€“6 Ã— 3.5â€“4 mm with glandular trichomes on midveins abaxially).
Sonerila souvannii
sp. nov. is also similar to
S. dongnathamensis
from Thailand in the shape of its inflorescences, but differs in the rhizome shape (cylindrical vs globose), the shape of the leaf base (cordate vs obtuse to rounded), pedicel length ( 10â€“25 mm long vs 1â€“4 mm long), the number of flowers per cyme (20â€“25 vs 5â€“12), and in the length and outline of the petals (9â€“10 Ã— 6â€“7 mm , acute vs 3â€“5 Ã— 3â€“4 mm , acuminate with long seta). The new species is also related to
S. tuberosa
from Cambodia , but distinguished in the rhizome shape (cylindrical vs slightly bulbous), the shape of the leaf base (cordate vs very broadly ovate to orbicular), pedicel length ( 10â€“25 mm long vs 5â€“6 mm long), the number of flowers per cyme (20â€“25 vs 4â€“8), and in the length and outline of the petals (9â€“10 Ã— 6â€“7 mm , acute vs 5 Ã— 2.7 mm , elliptic, apiculate, pink) ( Table 2 ).

subSubSection.paragraph: The specific epithet honours Keooudone Souvannakhoummane (Centre for Development and Environment), a plant taxonomist who has greatly contributed to our understanding of plant diversity in Laos through the description of many new species in various families for the flora of Laos .

Lithophytic perennial herb, 12â€“15 cm tall. Stem cylindrical, ca 2 cm long, 8â€“10 mm in diam., with a rhizome at the base, rhizome green when young then turning to brown with age, with rudimentary leaves on buds on the rhizome. Leaves forming a basal rosette; lamina (ordinary leaves) ovate, 8â€“10 Ã— 6â€“9 cm , membranous when dried, green, covered with hirsute hairs adaxially, pale green, covered with whitish hirsute hairs mainly along the veins abaxially, apex acute, base cordate, margin finely crenate and long ciliate, midrib sunken abaxially, with 4â€“5 pairs of lateral primary veins originating from a common point at the base, impressed adaxially, prominent abaxially; petiole 8â€“15 cm long, light green, densely villous except near base which is glabrous. Rudimentary leaves ovate, 0.2â€“0.6 cm long, with long spike hairs. Inflorescence terminal, scorpioid cyme, 20â€“25-flowered, of which 2â€“3 flowering at a time; peduncle 8â€“12 cm long, 2â€“2.5 mm in diam., sparsely covered with villous hairs. Bracts rachis and minute. Hypanthium greenish pink, campanulate, 5â€“6 mm long, 2â€“2.5 mm in diam., sparsely covered with villous hairs, Calyx lobes 3, ovate-triangular, ca 1 Ã— 2.5 mm , apex short acuminate; pedicel 1â€“2.5 cm long, 0.8â€“1 mm in diam., sparsely covered with glandular trichomes. Petals 3, elliptic, 9â€“10 Ã— 6â€“7 mm , pinkish purple adaxially, pale pink tinged with shiny green, with a pinkish purple line along the midrib abaxially. Stamens 3, anthers lanceolate, 5.5â€“6 mm long, bright yellow, basally inflated and deep cordate, filaments 6â€“7 mm long, glabrous, white. Ovary 3-locular, elliptical, placentation axillary, style 10â€“12 mm long, glabrous, white, stigma capitate. Capsule ovoid-ellipsoid, 5â€“7 Ã— 2.5 mm , smooth outside. Seeds brown, numerous.

Sonerila souvannii
sp. nov. grows in loose soil in the crevices of shaded rocks at 200â€“210 m a.s.l. It grows in the understorey of lowland semi-evergreen forest together with
Begonia martabanica A.DC.
( Begoniaceae C.Agardh ),
Phyllagathis tuberosa (C.Hansen) Cellin. & S.S.Renner
( Melastomataceae Juss. ) and
Davallia denticulata
(Burm. f.) Mett. ex Kuhn ( Davalliaceae M.R.Schomb. ex A.B.Frank ). Flowering and fruiting in September.

We found three small sub-populations of
S. souvannii
sp. nov. with each comprising only 5â€“6 individuals, about 20 m apart. The species has not yet been found anywhere else. Considering the species grows in a very narrowly restricted area where human activity, such as collection of non-timber forest products (NTFPs) and the logging of wood for local uses, can be seen, we need to pay attention to its conservation. As the number of mature individuals is less than 50, we assess this species as Critical Endangered (CR) criteria D ( IUCN 2019 ).
